div.p: THE CITY WIT, OR, The Woman wears the BREECHES.
LONDON, Printed by T. R. for Richard Marriot, and Thomas Dring, and are to be sold at their Shops in Fleet-street, 1653.

div.head: The Prologue.

opener.salute: Quot quot adestis, salvete, salvetote Gentlemen,

div.p:
YOu see I come unarm'd among you, sine Virga aut Ferula, without Rod or Ferular, which are the Pedants weapons. Id est, that is to say, I come not hither to be an Instructor to any of you, that were Aquilam volare docere, aut Delphinum natare, to teach the Ape, well learned as my selfe. Nor came I to instruct the Comedians. That were for me to be Asinus inter simias, the fool o'the Company: I dare not undertake them. I am no Paedagogus nor Hypodidascalus here. I approach not hither ad erudiendum, nec ad Corrigendum. Nay I have given my Schollars leave to play, to get a Vacuum for my selfe to day, to Act a particle here in a Play; an Actor being wanting that could beare it with port and state enough. A Pedant is not easily imitated. Therefore in person, I for your delight have
left my Schoole to tread the Stage. Pray Jove the terror of my brow spoile not your mirth, for you cannot forget the fury of a Tutor, when you have layne under the blazing Comet of his wrath, with quaeso Praeceptor te precor da— &c. But, let feare passe, nothing but mirth's intended.
But I had forgot my selfe, A Prologue should be in Rhyme, &c. therefore I will begin agen.

lg.l: Kind Gentlemen, and men of gentle kinde,
There is in that a figure, as you'll finde,
Because weel take your eares as 'twere in Ropes,
Ile nothing speak but figures, strayns & tropes.
Quot quot adestis Salvete salvetote.
The Schoolemaster that never yet besought yee,
Is now become a suitor, that you'll sit,
And exercise your Judgement with your wit,
On this our Comedy, which in bold Phrase,
The Author sayes has past with good applause
In former times. For it was written, when
It bore just Judgement, and the seal of Ben
Some in this round may have both seen't, and heard,
Ere I, that beare its title, wore a Beard.
My sute is therefore that you will not looke,
To find more in the Title then the Booke.
My part the Pedant, though it seem a Columne
Is but a Page, compar'd to the whole volume.
What bulk have I to bear a Scene to passe,
But by your favours multiplying Glasse.
In nova fert Animus, then Ile do my best
To gaine your Plaudite among the rest.
So with the salutation I first brought yee,
Quot quot adestis, salvete salvetote.

div.head: The City Wit. OR, The woman wears the Breeches.
Scene I.
div.stage: A Dinner carryed over the Stage in covered Dishes. Exeunt.
A Table set forth with empty Mony-bags, Bills, Bonds, & Bookes of accompts, &c.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Will you not go in and dine, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No: I am of other dyet to day.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: The whole company expects you.

lg.l: May they sit merry with their cheer,
while I feed on this hard meat. And wait
you within: I shall not change a trencher.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Alas my good Master.

lg.l: Here are the nests, but all the He takes up the bags.
Birds are flown.
How easie a thing it is to be undone,
When credulous Man will trust his 'state to others!
Am I drawn dry? Not so much as the Lees left?
Nothing but empty Cask? have I no refuge
To fly to now? Yes, here, about a groats worth He takes up the bils & papers.
Of paper it was once. Would I had now
Greens groats-worth of wit for it. But 'twill serve
To light tobacco-pipes. Here (let me see)
Here is three hundred pound, two hundred here.
And here one hundred, and two hundred here;
Fifty; fifty; fifty; and one hundred here,
And here one hundred and fifty. Besides
A many parcells of small debts, which make
Two hundred more. I shall not live to tell it,
But put it up, and take it by the weight. He puts the Bills & Bonds into a Bag.
O me! how heavy 'tis! And, doubtless, so 'twould be
At some mans heart. It troubles me a little. Enter Jeremy.
Now what newes?
My mistriss, and your Mother Sir,
Intreats you to come to dinner.
These they are; My debts,
That strike me through. This bag will never pay
Any of these.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Sir, shall I say you'l come?

lg.l: How well it were, if any of my Creditors
Could once but dream that this were current mony!

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Even what thou wilt, good Jeremy.

lg.l: Alas you know, this dinner was appointed
A friendly meeting for most of your Creditors,
And many of your Debtors.
But I hope
Few of the last appeare.
None but some priviledg'd Courtiers, that dare
Put in at all mens Tables. They're all set,
Your Creditors on one side, and your Debtors
On t'other; and do only stay for you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: To feed on; do they? Goe. I will not come.

lg.l: I feare, Sir, you will overthrow the good
That was intended you. You know this meeting
Was for the Creditors to give longer day,
As they should find your Debtors to acknowledg
The summes they owe you. Sir I should be sorry
To see you sinck, or forc'd to hide your head,
That look'd as high, as any in the City.
Prithee go in. And if they seem to stay,
Pray 'em fall too; tell 'em I take this time
Only to order my Accompts, and that as soon
As they are full, and fit to talk, I'le come:
Good Jeremie goe.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Introth I pity him—

lg.l: A right good Boy thou art. I think on thee:
What must I do now? All I have is lost,
And what I have not, sought to be forc'd from me,
I must take nimble hold upon Occasion,
Or lie for ever in the Bankrupt ditch,
Where no man lends a hand to draw one out.
I will leape over it, or fall bravely in't,
Scorning the Bridge of Baseness, Composition,
Which doth infect a City like the Plague,
And teach men Knavery, that were never born to't:
Whereby the Rope-deserving Rascall gains
Purple and Furrs, Trappings and golden Chaines.
Base Composition, baser far then Want,
Then Beggery, Imprisonment, Slavery:
I scorn thee, though thou lov'st a Trades-man dearly
And mak'st a Chandler Lord of thousands yearly.
I will have other ayd. How now! Againe?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: O, Sir, you are undone.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Hast thou no newes, Jeremie?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Alas your Mother Sir—

lg.l: Why what of her?
Is there a Plate lost, or a 'Postle-spoon
A China Dish broke, or an ancient Glass,
And stain'd with Wine her Damasque table-cloath?
Or is the Salt faln towards her? What's the matter?
Her mischievous tongue has over-thrown the good
Was meant to you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What Good, good Jeremie?

lg.l: Your Creditors were on a resolution
To do you good, and madly she oppos'd it,
And with a vehement voyce proclaims you a Beggar;
Says, you have undone her Daughter; that no good
Is fit to be done for you: And such a storm
Of wicked breath—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: She's drunk; Is she not, Jeremie?

lg.l: No Sir, 'tis nothing but her old disease,
The Tongue-ague, whose fit is now got up
To such a height, the Devil cannot lay it.
The learned School-master, Mr. Sarpego
Has conjur'd it by all his parts of speech,
His Tropes and Figures; and cannot be heard
I'th furious Tempest. All your Creditors
Are gone in Rage; will take their course, they say.
Some of your Debtors stay, I think, to laugh at her.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Now deafeness seize me. I disclaime my hearing. I defie my audituall part. I renounce mine ears. Mistris Pyannet, a desperate Palsey is on thy lips, and an everlasting Feaver on thy Tongue?

lg.l: What raging Rout hath rent thy rest;
What Scold hath scutch'd thy skonce:

sp.speaker: Sar.

lg.l: I'le breath it to thy bolder breast,
That askst me for the nonce.

sp.p: You understand or know, that here hath been a Feast made, to take up a ponderous difference between Master Sneakup your Father in Law, and your selfe Mr. Crasy; and between most of your Creditors and Debitors. Food hath been eaten; Wine drunck; Talke past; Breath spent; Labour lost: For why? Mistris Pyannet your Mother in Law, Mr. Sneakups Wife (though shee will be call'd by none but her owne name) that woman of an eternall Tongue; that Creature of an everlasting noyse; whose perpetuall talke is able to deafen a Miller; whose discourse is more tedious then a Justices Charge; Shee, that will out-scold ten carted Bawds, even when she is sober; and out-chat fifteen Midwives, though fourteen of them be halfe drunk: this Shee-thing hath burst all. Demosthenes himselfe would give her over. Therefore hopeless Sarpego is silent.

div.stage: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Sir Andrew Ticket, Rufflit, La. Ticket, Josina, Linsy-Wolsy.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
O, are you here Sir! You have spun a fair thred.
Here's much ado, and little help. We can make bolt nor shaft, find neither head nor foot in your business. My daughter and I may both curse the time, that ever we saw the eyes of thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir, you have the civill vertue of Patience in you. Dear Sir hear me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He sayes he heares thee, and is asham'd to see thee. Hast not undone our Daughter? spent her Portion; deceiv'd our hopes; wasted thy fortunes; undone thy credite; prov'd Bankrupt?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: All was but my kind heart in trusting, in trusting, Father.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Kind heart! What should Citizens do with kind hearts; or trusting in any thing but God, and ready money?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What would you, dear Father, that I should do now?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Marry depart in peace Sir. Vanish in silence Sir. I'le take my Daughter home Sir. She shall not beg with you Sir. No marry shalt thou not; no, 'deed Duck shalt thou not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Be yet but pleased to answer me, good Sir. May not an honest man—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Honest man! Who the Devill wish'd thee to be an honest man? Here's my worshipfull Husband, Mr. Sneakup, that from a Grasier is come to be a Justice of Peace: And, what, as an honest man? Hee grew to be able to give nine hundred pound with my daughter; and, what, by honestie? Mr. Sneakup and I are come up to live i'th City, and here we have lyen these three years; and what? for honesty? Honesty! What should the City do with honesty; when 'tis enough to undoe a whole Corporation? Why are your Wares gumm'd; your Shops dark; your Prizes writ in strange Characters? what, for honesty? Honesty? why is hard waxe
call'd Merchants waxe; and is said seldome or never to be rip'd off, but it plucks the skin of a Lordship with it? what! for honesty? Now (mortified my Concupiscence!) Dost thou think, that our Neighbour, Master Linsy-Wolsie here, from the sonne of a Tripe-wife, and a Rope-maker, could aspire to be an Aldermans Deputy; to be Worshipfull Mr. Linsie-Wolsie; Venerable Mr. Linsie-wolsie; to weare Sattin sleeves, & whip Beggars? And, what? By honesty? Have we bought an Office, here, for our towardly and gracious son and heire here, young Mr. Sneakup—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes forsooth Mother.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: And made him a Courtier, in hope of his honesty? Nay, (once for all) Did we marry our Daughter, here, to thee; rack'd our Purses to pay Portion; left Country house-keeping to save charges, in hope either of thine, or her honesty? No, we look'd, that thy Ware-house should have eaten up Castles, and that for thy narrow Walke in a Jewellers shop, a whole Countrey should not have suffic'd thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: If my uncunning Disposition be my only vice, then Father—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay, and thou hast been married three years to my Daughter, and hast not got her with Child yet! How do'st answer that? For a woman to be married to a fruitfull Fool, there is some bearing with him yet. (I know it by my self) but a dry barren Fool! How dost thou satisfie that?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: It may be defect in your Daughter, as probable as in me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: O impudent varlet! Defect in my Daughter? O horrible indignity! Defect in my Daughter? Nay, 'tis well known, before ever thou sawest her, there was no defect in my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Well: If to be honest, be to be a fool, my utmost
Ambition is a Coxcomb. Sir, I crave your farewell.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Marry Sir, and have it with all his heart. My Husband is a man of few words, and hath committed his tongue to me: And I hope I shall use it to his Worship. Fare you well Sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Thanks for your cheer and full bounty of Entertainment, good Mr. Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He rather thanks you for your patience, and kind visitation, good Sir Andrew Ticket. Yes indeed forsooth does he.

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: I take my leave Sir, too.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Good Madame—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Uds so! ther's a trick! you must talk, must you? And your Wife in presence, must you? As if I could not have said, good Madame. Good Madame! Do you see how it becomes you?

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: Good Mistris Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Good Madame, I beseech your Ladiship to excuse our deficiency of Entertainment. Though our power be not to our wish, yet we wish that our Power were to your Worth, which merrits better service—

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: Pardon me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Then our rudenesse—

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: You wrong your selfe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Can tender, or possibly expresse by—

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: I beseech you forsooth—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Our best labour, or utmost devoire. Yes I protest sweet Madame. I beseech you, as you passe by in Coach sometimes, vouchsafe to see me; and, if I come to Court, I will presume to visite your Ladiship, and your worthy Knight, Good Sir Andrew! And I pray you Madame, how does your Monckey, your Parrot, and Parraquitoes? I pray commend me to 'em, and to all your little ones. Fare you well, sweet Creature.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Wee'll leave you to take private farewell of your Wife, Mr. Crasie.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Wee'l meet you at your Horse, brother.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Lov'd, my deare heart, my sweetest, my very being, will you needs take your journey? I shall fall before your return into a Consumption. If you die but conceive what your departure will bring upon me, I know (my sweet) nay I do know— but goe your ways; strike my finger into mine eye: 'Tis not the first true teare a married woman has shed.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why you heare the noyse of that woman of Sound, your Mother. I must travell down, or not keep up. Yet—

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Nay, goe I beseech you; you shall never say, I undid you. Goe I pray: But never look to see me my owne woman again. How long will you stay forth?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: A fortnight at the least; and a moneth at the most.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Well, a fortnight at the least. Never woman took a more heavy departure. Kisse me. Farewel. Kiss me againe. I pray does your Horse amble, or trot? Do not ride post as you come home, I pray. Kisse me once more. Farewell.
Hay hoe! How I do gape.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What's a clock Bridget.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Past three forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Tis past sleeping time then, Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Nothing is past to those, that have a mind and means.

lg.l: That's true and tryed. Go lay my Pillow Bridget. Exit Brid.
Lord, what a thing a woman is in her Husbands absence!
Wast thou ever in love, Jeremy?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Who I forsooth? No forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: I forsooth, and no forsooth? then I perceive you are forsooth. But I advise you to take head, how you levell your Affection towards me: I am your Mistris; And I hope you never heard of any Apprentice was so bold with his Mistris.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: No indeed forsooth. I should be sorry there should be any such.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Nay, be not sorry neither Jeremy. Is thy Master gone? Look. A pretty youth, this same Jeremy! And is come of a good Race. I have heard my Mother say, his Father was a Ferretter—

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: He is gone forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Come hither Jeremy. Dost thou see this Handkerchief?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: I vow'd this Handkerchief should never touch any bodies face, but such a one, as I would intreat to lie with me.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Indeed forsooth!

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Come hither Jeremy. There's a spot o'thy Cheek, let me wipe it off.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: O Lord forsooth. I'le go wash it.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Heaven made this Boy of a very honest Appetite, sober Ignorance, and modest Understanding. My old Grandmothers Latine is verified upon him; Ars non habet Inimicum praeter Ignorantem. Ignorance is womans greatest Enemy. Who's within? Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Go your wayes to Mistresse Parmisan, the Cheesmongers Wife in old Fishstreet, and commend me to her; and intreat her to pray Mistresse Collifloore the Hearb-woman in the Old Change, that she will desire Mistris Piccadell in Bow-lane, in any hand to beseech the good old dry Nurse mother, Et cetera, shee knowes where, to provide me an honest, handsome, secret young man; that can write, and read written hand. Take your errand with you; that can write and read written hand.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I warrant you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: So, now will I meditate, take a nap, and dreame out a few fancies.

div.head: Sene II.
div.stage: Enter Crasy, booted. Ticket, Rufflit, Tobias Sarpego, Linsy woolsy:

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: WEE take our leaves Mr. Crasy, and wish good Journey to you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Farewell good Mr. Crasy.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Adiue Brother.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Iterum iterumque vale.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Heartily Godbuy, good Mr. Crasy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay but Gentlemen: A little of your patience you all know your own Debts, and my almost impudent necessities, satisfie me, that J may discharge others. Will you suffer me to sink under my Freenes? shall my goodnesse, and ready Pietie undoe me? Sir Andrew Ticket, you are a profest Courtier, and should have a tender sense of honor. This is your day of payment for two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Blood of Bacchus, tis true, tis my day, what then? Dost take me for a Cittizen, that thou thinkest I'll keep my day? No, thou'st find that I am a Courtier, let my day keep me and 'twill. But dost heare? Come to the Court. J will not say what I will do for thee. But come to the Court. I ow the two hundred pounds: I'll not deny't, if thou ask seven years hence for't, farewell. I say no more, but come to the Court, and see if I will know thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O, Sir, now you are in favour, you will know no body.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: True: tis just. Why should we, when we are in favour know any body; when, if we be in disgrace, no body will know us? Farewell honest Tradesman.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: That is Synonima for a fool. An ironicall Epithite, upon my Facunditie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O Master Sarpego! I know you will satisfie your own driblet of ten pound, I lent you out of my Purse.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Diogenes Laertius on a certaine time, demanding of Cornelius Tacitus an Areopagit of Syracusa; what was the most Commodious and expeditest method to kill the Itch, answered—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Answer me my monyes I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Peremptorily, Careo Supinis; I want money. I confesse, some driblets are in the Debet. But, me thinks
, that you being a Man of Wit, Braine, Forecast and Forehead, should not be so easie, (I will not say foolish, for that were a figure) as to lend a Philosopher money, that cryes, when he is naked, Omnîa mea mecum porto. Well Sir, J shall ever live to wish, that your owne Lanthorne may be your direction; and that, where ever you travell, the Cornu copia of Abundance may accompany you. Yes sure shall I. Vive valeque.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why look you Brother, It was thought, that I had a tender Pericranion; or, in direct Phrase, that I was an unthrifty fool. Signior no: you shall now find, that I cannot only keep mine own, but other mens. It is rightly said, He that is poor in Appetite, may quickly be rich in Purse. Desire little; covet little; no not your own: And you shall have enough.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Enough?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes Brother, litle enough. I confesse I am your Debtor for the loane of some hundred Marks. Now you have need: who has not? you have need to have it. I have need to pay it. Here's need of all hands. But Brother, you shall be no looser by me. Purchase Wit; Get wit (look you) wit. And Brother, if you come to the Court, now my Mother and my Father have bought me an Office there, so you will bring my Sister with you, I will make the best shew of you that I can. It may chance to set you up againe, Brother; tis many an honest mans fortune, to rise by a good Wife. Farewell sweet Brother. Prithee grow rich againe; and weare good Cloaths, that we may keep our Acquaintance still. Farewell, deare Brother. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Mr. Rufflit—

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What, does thy fist gape for mony from me?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I hope it is not the fashion, for a Gallant of fashion, to break for so small a Portion as the summe of an hundred Angells.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: For a Gallant of fashion to break, for a Gallant of fashion? Dost thou know what a Gallant of fashion is? I'll tell thee. It is a thing that but once in three Moneths has money in his Purse; A creature made up of Promise and Protestation: A thing that foules other mens Napkins: towseth other Mens Sheets, flatters all he feares, contemns all he needs not, sterves all that serve him, and undoes all that trust him. Dost ask me mony, as I am a Gallant of fashion, I do thee Curtesie, I beat thee not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I lent it you on your single word.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Tis pittie but thou shouldest loose thy Freedom for it: you Tradesmen have a good Order in your Citty, Not to lend a Gentleman money without a Cittizen bound with him: But you forsooth scorne Orders! By this light, tis pitty thou loosest not thy Freedome for it. Well, when I am flush, thou shalt feel from mee, Farewell. Prithee learne to have some witt. A handsome streight young fellow, grown into a pretty Bear, with a proper bodyed Woman to his Wife, and cannot beare a Braine! Farewell. Dost heare? Be rul'd by me, Get money, do, Get money and keep it; wouldst thrive? Be rather a knave then a Fool. How much dost say I ow thee?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Thou art in my Debt. I have given the Counsell worth threeskore, Dog-cheap, well I'll rent the odde mony.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Strange mad fellows these same, Mr. Crasie, me thinks to deale withall.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
You are right Mr. Linsie wolsie! I would my Genius had directed me, to deale alwayes with such
honest neighbourly men as your selfe. I hope you will not deny me a Curtesie.

sp.speaker: Lins.
sp.p: Not I, I protest, what is it?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You took once a Jewell of me, which you sold for thirty pound, for which I have your Bond for sixty, at your day of mariage. If you will now, because I want present money, give me but twenty pound, I'll acquit you.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: My good friend Mr. Crasie, I have no tricks and Jerks to come over you, as the witty Gentleman had ere while: But I know a plaine bargaine is a plaine bargaine: and wit is never good till it be bought. If twentie pound will pleasure you, upon good security I will procure it you. A hundred if you please, do you mark Mr. Crasie? On good security. Otherwise you must pardon me, Mr. Crasie. I am a poore Tradesman Mr. Crasie, keep both a Linnen and a Wollen Drapers shop, Mr. Crasie, according to my name, Mr. Crasie, and would be loth to lend my money, Mr. Crasie, to be laught at among my Neighbours, Mr. Crasie, as you are Mr. Crasie. And so fare you wel, Mr. Crasie.

sp.speaker: Cra.

lg.l: Is this the end of unsuspicious Freenesse?
Are open hands of Chearfull Pietie,
A helpfull bounty, and most easie Goodnesse,
Rewarded thus?
Is, to be honest, term'd to be a fool?
Respect it Heaven. Beare up still merry heart.
Droop not: But scorne the worlds unjust despising.
Who through Goodnesse sinks, his fall's his Rising.

sp.p: O Master, Master, upon my knowledge, my Mistres is forced since your departure to be

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What Jeremy?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Honest Sir. Get up your Debts as fast as you can abroad: For on my understanding (which great Iove knowes is but little) shee will take up more then your due at home easily.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Boy. Didst never observe at the Court gate, that the Lord was no sooner off from his Horse-back but the Lackey got up into the Saddle and rode home?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes Sir, tis common.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I scorne not my Betters Fortune. And what is not my sinne, shall never be my shame.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Introth I was faine to make my selfe an Asse, or else I had been tempted to have been a knave.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Boy, thou art now my Prentice. From hence be free. Poverty shall serve it selfe. Yet do one thing for me.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: If it be in the power of my poore Sconce.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If ever it be in thy possible ability, wrong all Men, use thy wit, to abuse all things, that have but sence of wrong: For without mercie, all men have injur'd thy mistrustles Master, Milk'd my thoughts from my heart, and money from my Purse, and, last, laught at my Credulity. Cheat, chosen, live by thy Wits: Tis most manly, therefore most noble. Horses get their living by their Backs, Oxen by their necks, Swine and Women by their Flesh, Only man by his Braine. In briefe be a knave and prosper: For honesty has beggerd me.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Farewell Master. And if I put tricks upon some of them, let the end of the Comedie demonstrate.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I am resolv'd I will revenge. I never provok'd my braine yet. But now if I clap not fire in the tayles of some of these Samsons Foxes— seems my defect of Fortune want of wit? Noe.

lg.l: The sense of our slight sports confess'd shall have,
That any may be rich, will be a knave.

div.head: Scene I.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: EGregious and most great of Expectation, my right dignified and truly Ciceronian Pupill, now that I have brought you into the Amoene fields with my ready thankfullnesse for the loane of this ten pound, I commit you to the grace of Court.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I shall expect that money shortly. Care to send it; For I purchas'd my place at a rack'd recompence.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Your Sarpego is no slipperie Companion. You know I am to marry, and this money shall provide me Complements.
sp.quote: Sis bonus o faelixque tuis. I pede fausto.

div.stage: Enter Crasy like a lame Souldier.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Belov'd of Phoebus, Minion of the Muses, deare Water Bayley of Helicon, let it not be distastfull to thy Divine eares, to receive the humble Petition of a poore Creature, made miserable by the policie of Providence. That thy rare and absolute munificence might supply what fortune had left defective: I kisse thy learned toes.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I tell thee, by the Axiomes of the Peripateticall Aristotle, thou art a Monster. My reward shall be therefore like thy selfe, monstrously lame. This is a figure in Eloquution call'd Apoxegesis.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I am not fed with Figures Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You are an idle vagabond, and lye in wait for the blood of the learned. Labour, and live.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Right eloquent and well-phrased Sir, my education has been liberall. I sometimes fed my flock on horned Parnassus: But my wants forc'd me to my Sword.

div.stage: He shews his blade halfe way.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You did peradventure sip on the top of Science, Primoribus labijs, or so, but did not convert it in Succum & sanguinem.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: That I may ever remaine a true man— Extend.

The Sun, Moon and the seven Planets are my invoked witnesses, I should be grieved, that necessity should make me grow violent on so adored, adorned Grammaticall Disciplinary— Be gracious in Contribution— Sir—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: J will give thee an infinite treasure. Sis integer vitae, scelerisque purus. Vale poore Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir, this Sword can bite— But, J know you had rather give it freely out of your own Proclivitie.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Yes I protest, as I am Erudite. Here dreadfull Mavortian, the poor price of a Dinner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If I might in modesty importune the poore price of a Supper too.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I do speak it in the Optative Mood, I do wish it lay in the modell of my Fortune to give harbour to your shaken state, yet receive this with appeased clutch.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
If I might not seem audacious even to impudence, I poore Freshman in Literature, would implore
of your well-salted, & best season'd vertue, some larger allowance to supply my defects of Rayment, Books, and other necessaries: which magnificence shall ever intitle you, my most bounteous Macaenas. Be induc'd to it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar:
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, that you may know how deare you are to me; Know this is more then usuall largesse— for non omnibus dormio— There's a Figure too.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O yes Sir, I understand this Figure too very well. Now deare Mecenas, let me implore a Purse to inclose these Monyes in— Nay if you impart not with a chearfull forhead, Sir

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Vae misero mihi! sweet Purse adieu. Iterum iterumque vale.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: May you be importun'd to do it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You shall have it instantly. I will only deprome, or take out a little stuffing first.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Tis no matter. As it is, As it is, good Sir, as it is. Ile accept it as it is. Most fragrant-phrased Master, suffer thy selfe to be intreated. Doe—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You have most powerfully perswaded: Take it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Most exorbitantly bounteous Mecenas, you have given me all this, have you not?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and you have taken all that, have you not?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but as your gift. Iove blesse thy browes, and make cleer thy Phisnomy. Vale. Your learned Worship stincks.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Now Barbarisme, Incongruity, and false Orthography shame thee; The curse of Priscian take thee. All the parts of speech
defie thee. All the Interjections of sorrow, as Heu hei, of Shunning, as Apage; of Disdaining, as Hem vah; of Scorning, as Hui; of Exclaiming, as Proh Deum atque hominum fidem take thee. My deare Pupils lendings hast thou lewdly lick'd away: And sorrowfull Sarpego is lick'd dry. There's a figure left yet! But ô thou Castalion Traytor, Pick-purse of Parnassus, and Hang-man of Helicon: Dives thirst in thy Throat; Ixions wheel on thy back; Tantalus hunger in thy guts; and Sisyphus stone in thy Bladder.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O fearfull curse! Well; I haye given my first pinch, and a little scratch'd my Goat-bearded Grammarian, that Broke jests on my uncunning easiness. But he with the rest shall feele, that modest Simplicity is not alwayes a defect of wit, but will: What my willing honesty hath seem'd to loose, my affected deceits shall recover. I'le rid 'em one after another, like Guts, till they shall stink worse then Jewes.

lg.l: And they shall find with most ashamed eyes,
The honest Breast lives only rich and wise.

sp.speaker: JOs.
sp.p: Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Bridget, I say.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here, Lady.

lg.l: That's comfortably spoken! Nay blush not:
We women can never have too much given us. And
Madame, Josina would sound well.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Madame Josina Crasie.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: No; not Crasie; hang Crasie: Crasie is my Husbands name. I wonder why Women must be called by their Husbands names, I.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O, they must forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: And why not men by their Wives?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Marrie forsooth, because that Men, when they marry, become but halfe men: And the other half goes to their Wives. And therefore she is called Woman; where before she was call'd but Mayd.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Is a married Man but halfe a Man? what is his other halfe then?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Truly, oftentimes, Beast. Which part the wife gives to boot, in exchange of her name. One knocks.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Heark, some body knocks; goe see. What should any body knock at my Garden door for? I doe not use to be visited in my Garden.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Yonder's a Gentleman craves admittance to converse with you.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: I'le converse with no Gentleman. What have I to do with Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: A fair-spoken, comely, modest Gentleman he is.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Is he so? I'le speak with no modest Gentleman. You were best be his Bawd. But are you sure he is a true Gentleman? does he weare clean Linnen, and lack Money?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here he comes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: He is very confident, and forward, me thinks.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Exquisite; very Elixir of Beauty, vouchsafe to receive the tender of my Faith to you; which I protest is zealously devoted to your particular service.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: You may speak lowder Sir: for I assure you, my Mayd is very thick of hearing, and exceeding weake sighted.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Then, Lady, let it be spoken in bold phrase, I love you.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: I thank you Sir. How should I stile you, pray?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
My name is Pulse-feel: A poor Doctor of Physick, that weares three-pile velvet in his Cap; has paid a quarters rent of his house afore-hand; and as meanly as he stands here, was made Doctor beyond the Seas. I vow (as I am right Worshipfull) the taking of my Degree cost me twelve French crowns, and five and thirty pound of salt Butter in upper Germany. I can make your beauty, and preserve it; Rectifie your Body, and maintain it; perfume your skin; tinct your haire; enliven your Eye; Heighten your Appetite. As for Gellies, Dentifrices, Diets, Minerall Fucusses, Pomatums, Fumes, Italian Masks to sleep in, either to moysten, or
dry the Superficies of your face; paugh, Gallen was a Goose, and Paracelsus a Patch to Doctor Pulse-feel. Make me then happy, deare sweeting, in your private favours: The which I vow with as much secrefie, constancie and Resolution, to preserve, as you, with Bounty, sweetnesse and Freenes shall impart.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: I protest you speak very farre within me; I respect you most affectionatly.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Then Ile attend you at your Chamber: where the best pleasure, youth, Cupid can minister shall entertaine you.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Entertain me with pleasure? what pleasure I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nothing but kisse you Lady, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Well, for kissing and so forth, I care not; But look for no dishonesty at my hands, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will be provident.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: And honest, I beseech you: And secret, and resolute, I advise you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: And very chast I command you. But a kisse, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I understand you. This be my pledg of faith.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: And this of mine.— The thought of me rest with you. And heare you Doctor; I prithee procure me some young Fellow, that can write: For I am so troubled with Letters, that I neither read nor answer—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Rely upon me. I can fit you rarely. I know a well qualified fellow, that danceth rarely, playes on divers
Instruments, and withall is close.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: I marry, Close! Pray let me have him. Kisse and adiew.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will maintain it. He only, that knows it, permits, and procures it, is truly a Cuckold. Some fellow would be divorc'd now. Crasie, speak; wilt be divorc'd? why, what and I were? why then thou art an Asse, Crasie. Why Sir? why Sir! why prithee tell me, what would thy Divorce hurt her? It would but give her more liberty. Shee should have bounteous Customers; Gallants, that would hoist her tires, bestow deep on her. And she should be paid for't. You speak somewhat to the matter Sir. Nay Crasie, believe it, though she be not a very modest woman for a Wife, thou mayst force her to be a reasonable private wench for a Whore. Say you so? Birlady, and I'le take your Counsell. 'Tis a pretty Drabb. I know not where to compasse such another? troth Sir, I'le follow your advice.

lg.l: And, if my hopes prove not extreamly ill,
I'le keep her flesh chast, though against her will.
He tooke her by the middle so small
And laid her on the Plain:
And when he had his will on her,
He tooke her up againe.
And what was she then the worse for wearing?
Can you tell Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Crac:
sp.p: One Sir (I dare tell you in private) that can conduct you to a more lovely Creature, then her you last courted.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: A young Pimpe, a very sucking-pig Pimpe! What an Age is this, when children play at such great game! So young, so forward!

lg.l: The young and the old mun too't, mun too't,
The young and the old mun to it;
The young ones will learn to do't, to do't,
And the Old forget not to do it.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: This Infant piece of Impudence amazes me. Prithee what art thou? or whom dost thou serve, or broke for.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: As delicate a piece of Woman-flesh as ever Mortall laid lip to. O she is all Venus! And, to come close to you, shee wants a Physician. You are one I take it: I am a foole else.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I am catch'd? This habite will betray me. What is shee, I say.

lg.l: O she is, she is a matchlesse piece,
Though all the world may wooe her;
Nor golden showre, nor golden fleece,
Is price enough to do her.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: For what wants she a Physitian?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p:
For what you please, when you come to her. Sir, upon my life, shee's free from any Disease, but the Counterfeits. Will you know all Sir? she wants a wise mans counsell to assist her in getting a Husband. I take hold of you for that wise man, shee relyes upon my Election. Will you go Sir? Tis in an exceeding civill
house; a precise one, indeed. Know you not Mr. Linsey Woolsey?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Not at his house?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir. At his very house. All the wise wenches i'the Town will thwack to such Sanctuaries, when the times are troublesome, and Troopers trace the streets in terror.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Prithee, what call'st thy Mistres?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: There she lies Sir, by the name of Mistresse Tryman; a rich young Cornish Widdow; though she was borne in Clearken-well; and was never halfe a dayes Journey from Bride well in her life. Her Father was a Pinn-maker— Sings.

lg.l: Along along, where the Gallants throng
By twenties, away the Widow to carry:
But let them tarry: For shee will carry
Twenty, before that one she will Marry.

sp.p: Will you along Sir?

lg.l: Tis but a weak ingagement: yet Ile goe;
Needlesse are feares, where Fortunes are so low.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A Widdow! what is shee? or of whence?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: A lustie young wench, they say: A Cornish Girle; able to wrastle downe stronger Chines then any of ours.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: But how is she purs'd, Jack? Is she strong that way?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Prettie well for a younger Brother; worth 7 or 8 thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: How man!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You are a married man, and cannot Rivall me; I would not else be so open to you.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I sweare Ile help thee all I can. How didst find her out?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I have intelligence, that never failes me, shee came to town neither but very lately; and lodg'd at Mr. Wolseys.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Who, Linsy wolsie, the Hermaphroditicall Draper! That's a precious Nott-headed Rascall. Hee'll goe neare to ayme at her himselfe.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Like enough. He may aime at her: But shee will be hit by none but a Gentleman, that I heare too Oh shee has a fierce Ambition to a Ladyship, though her late Husband was a Tanner.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A Tanner, well Jack, cake heed how thou ventur'st on her to make her a Gentlewoman: She will kill thee at her Husbands occupation before thou wile be able to make her Hide gentle. Thou wilt find a tough peece of Curriers work on her. Look who here is.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Truly Mr. Toby Sneakup, me thinks I find an alteration in my selfe already.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Nay, I told you; would you but give your Mind to it, you would be a Gentleman quickly.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: How's this? let's stand aside a little.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sure, hee's about to turne himselfe into a Gentleman to winne to the Widdow!

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: And what a Tutor he has pickt out to instruct him!

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Me thinks I love the name of a Gentleman a great deale better then I did.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: But could you find in your heart to lend a Gentleman a score of Angells, Mr. Wolsey, on his word?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Uhm— I is not gone so farre upon me yet.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh, but it must though, I know it. A Citizen can never be a Gentleman, till he has lent all, or almost all his money to Gentlemen. What a while it was ere the rich Joyners son was a Gentleman? when I my selfe was a Gentleman first, my mony did so burne in my Pockets, that it cost me all that ever I had, or could borrow, or steal from my Mother.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: But Mr. Toby, a man may be a Countrey Gentleman, and keep his money, may he not?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: You see Sir, This Widdow is remov'd from the Countrey into the City, to avoyd the multiplicity of Country Gentlemen that were here suitors. Nay you must be a Citty Gallant; or a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I see no Courtiers, but are more apt to borrow, then to lend.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I, those that were born, or bred Courtiers I grant you, But to come to't at your yeares—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I can the sooner learne. Your Courtier Sir, I pray.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ile tell you in a breife character was taught me. Speake nothing that you mean, performe nothing that you promise, pay nothing that you owe, flatter all above you, scorne all beneath you, deprave all in private, praise all in publike; keepe no truth in your mouth, no faith in your heart; no health in your bones, no freindship in your mind, no modesty in your eyes, no Religion in your conscience; but especially, no Money in your Purse.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O that Article spoyles all.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: If you do, take heed of spending it on any thing but Panders, Puncks, and Fidlers; for that were most unfashionable.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, for your Courtly and Gentlemanlike instructions, and wish you grace to follow them: I have seen too fearfull an example lately in my neighbour Crasy, whose steps I list not trace; nor lend my Money to be laught at among my Neighbours. Fare you well Sir.—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Wolsie! Well met. How does your faire Guest at home, Mrs. Tryman?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How should he come to the knowledge of her? Some of these Gallants will snatch her up, if I prevent not speedily.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why speak you not Mr. Wolsie? How does the Widow?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Truly not well Sir. Whether it be wearinesse of her journey, change of ayre, or dyet, or what I know not; something has distemperd her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or Love, perhaps of you Mr. Wolsie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Me? Alasse, I look like no such Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You may in a short time.
Harke hither Mr. Wolsie.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We overheard you man: And I guest as much before.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tis very true Sir, shee is worth nine thousand pound: But marry she will not' but a Gentleman: And I think I have beat him off o'th condition, I have put him off o' that scent for ever, with a false character, Heaven and the Court forgive me.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Thou hast introth Boy: And on purpose to have her thy selfe, I perceive it.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: He does not. He's an Asse.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Well, if I were a Batchelor, I should envy thy wit, and thy fortune. Is she very handsome?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: So so: You shall see wee'll make a shift with her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Wolsie, I would you had her with all my heart; you shall not want my good word and best wishes.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Do you speak this in earnest Sir, or as you are a Courtier:

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: In earnest I, and as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Then in earnest, and as I am an honest man, I do not beleeve you. Mr. Toby Sneakup has told me what Gentlemen and Courtiers are, too lately.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Sneakup. well met.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Good Mr. Rufflit.

lg.l: Now faire Mayds lay downe my Bed,
And draw the Curtaines round:
Tell the World that I am dead,
And who hath given the wound,
Ah me poor Soul!
Alack for love I dye,
Then to the Sexton hie,
And cause the Bell to towle.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: O here he is! Mr. Wolsie, indeed my Master Wolsie, if ever you will see my Mistres your Sweetheart alive, you must goe home presently.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: My Sweetheart!

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: I thinke shee is; and that in death she will be so. I speak by what she sayes, and others think.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tis the Widows Boy,

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Is she sicker then she was.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: O shee is even speechlesse, and calls for you exceedingly. I fetcht a Doctor to her, and he can do her no good. Master Sarpego has made her Will and all.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Has shee given me any thing?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Quickly goe and see Sir, you will come too late else, I am going to get the Bell to towle for her.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Fare ye well Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tic. Ruff. Nay, wee'll along with you.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Sing.

lg.l: Did never truer heart
Out of the World depart,
Or cause the Bel to towle.

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: Enter in the Tryman, attended by Isabell, Jone, Crasy, with an Urinall.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: LOok up Mistres.
Jo. Take a good heart, the worst is past, feare not.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Reach the Bottle againe of Doctor Stephens water.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No no, apply more warme cloaths to her stomack, there the matter lyes which sends this distemperature into her braine. Be of good cheer Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Is Mr Wolsie there?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Nothing but Mr. Wolsie ever in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Pray Sir, how do you like her? I am much affraid of her.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Let me see, to night it will be full Moon. And she scape the turning of the next Tyde, I will give her a gentle Vomit in the morning, that shall ease her stomack of this conflux of venomous humours, and make her able to sit a hunting Nag within this sennight.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: A rare man sure. And, I warrant, well seen in a Woman.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Well sayd, spit out gently, straine not your selfe too hard.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Agh— fagh.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Tis very well done. La'you. Her colour begins to come. Ile lay all my skill to a messe of Tewksbury Mustard, shee sneezes thrice within these three houres—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Good Sir want nothing, that your skill shall approve necessary in this time of need. Good Wives and kinde Neighbours, I thanke you for your cares.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Is Mr. Wolsie there?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: She does nothing but call for you Sir, pray speak to her.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Where's Mr. Wolsie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Here Lady. How do you?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Then I am even well me thinks— agh— agh—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Shee's very farr gone I feare, how do you find her disease Sir?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p:
Dangerous enough Sir. For shee is sicker in minde then in body. For I finde most plainely the effects of a deep melancholly, falne through her distemperature of passion upon her Liver; much disordering, and withall wasting the vitals, leaving scarce matter for Physick to worke on. So that her minde receiving
the first hurt, must receive the first cure.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Agh agh ah— pagh fagh—

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: So so: Straine not your selfe too hard. No hurt; so so.
Here's melancholly and choller both in plenty.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: He speaks with great reason, me thinks, and to the purpose, I would I understood him.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Do you not know, Sir, any that has offended her by open injury, or unkindnesse?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Alas Sir, no such thing could happen since her coming hither.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Then, on my life, tis Love that afflicts her.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh oh uh oh—

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I have toucht her to the quick. I have found her disease, and that you may prove the abler Doctor in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Who I? Alas I beleeve no such matter.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Mr. Wolsie, Mr. Wolsie.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Here he is Lady. Pray speak your minde to him. Must I pull you to her? Here he is. What do you say to him? Pray speak.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh no, no no no—

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: She hath something troubles her that concernes onely you. Pray take her by the hand, do as I intreat you. Lady we will go, and leave you in private awhile, if you please.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray do. O but do not, pray do not.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Do you perceive nothing in this passion of hers?
How does she feel your hand?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O, she does so quiddle it, shake it, and gripe it!

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: You are then the man Sir, the happy man. For she shall recover suddenly.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Who I? Alack a day.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: What will you have me dye intestate. Is not my Will made, as I directed?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Where are you Mr. Sarpego, with the Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Ad manum. Sweet Buds of Generosity, forbeare you may Admirare, at the abundance here specified: But not find a Legacie bequeath'd among you

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We expect nothing.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I only wish your health, Lady; and that it may, or might have been my happiness to sue to you for Love; as I do now to the highest power for Life.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Would I were married to her, as shee is; and twere but for an hower, I car'd not. Had my mother been but acquainted with her, before shee fell sick, here had been a match!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O Dij immortales! A rich Widdow shall have Suiters on her Death-bed.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Good Sir, It is too late to speak of these things. I only crave and wish your prayers in your absence: This place can yield no pleasure to you I know. Mr. Wolsey, pray your hand againe: I could be even content to live me thinks, if I had but such a man as you to my Huh, uh, uh, uh.—

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: By your leave. Pray by your leave. Help Women. Beare up her Body a little. Bow it forwards. So, speak to her, Sr. Good Lady drink of this Cordyal.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How do you now forsooth?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: What now shee is drinking— Now speake Sir, you or no man must do her good.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How do you forsooth?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Well said Sir, speak chearfully to her.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How dee doe? how dee doe, Mistris Tryman How ist now, ha?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Very comfortably spoken!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I, was it not?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Alas shee cannot speak. I'll call my Neighbour Mistres Sneakup. If any body can make her speak, 'tis shee.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I'll call my Mother for you. Shee will make her speak, if shee have but a word left in her belly— Masse here shee comes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How comes it Mr. Wolsey, that you have a Gentlewoman sick in your house, and not send for me? Let me feel her hand. Alasse she is shrewdly distemper'd. When had shee a stoole Sir, Prithee Daughter step home to my Closet, and bring the Viall of— my owne Water, which stands next to my blew Velvet Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: That's my Doctor was with me to day

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Shee's a young Gentlewoman; may have many Children yet, let me note her eyes: I finde nothing there. When did you see her water Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: What Devill sent this fury among us?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: In troth I beshrew you, Mr. Wolsey, you sent not for me, but I hope I come not too late. Pluck up a Womens heart, you shall find a good Neighbour of me.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I will thank you in my Will. I shall not live to thank you otherwise.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Alas talk not of your will. You shall have time enough to think of that many yeares hence.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I tell her so, Lady, yet shee calls for it still.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray let me see it, that I may signe it. Uh Uh—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Lord how my Daughter stayes. Good Sir Andrew Ticket! worthy Mr. Rufflit! My Sonne Tobias is highly honor'd in your noble Acquaintance, and Courtly conversation.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We rather hold our selves dignified, in being his indear'd Companions.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I assure you Mother, we are the three of the Court.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: I most intirely thank you for him. And I do beseech you make your selves no strangers to my poor house. Wee are alone; can give but light entertainement, my Daughter and I; since my Sonne Crasies misfortune drave him from us—
O welcome Daughter— I beseech you noble Sirs estrange not your selves to us, your Servants.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Pox o'your Complement.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Give me the Viall Daughter. Take up the Lady. Tast of this. It is a Composition of mine owne distilling.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, umh—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well done. Nay it will make you break wind, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: By the service I owe you sweet Mistres, tis unfained. My Wife desires to see you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
As I can best witnesse; And feares you enjoy not the libertie of a Woman, since your Husbands departure.
Your Brother having promis'd too, to conduct you to Court.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: It is confest, and I will do it.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Where the best entertainment a poore Ladyes chamber can afford, shall expect you.

sp.speaker: Ios
sp.p: I shall embrace it.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Sfoot, tis time to part you— Mistres, I beseech your help, joyn'd with your vertuous Mothers.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: You forget the young man, that can Dance Write, and keep Counsell.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I forget you not Lady. But I wish you to beware of these Courtiers, till I tell you what they are:

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if this Doctor be not of her smock Counsell.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How is it now, good heart?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Much enlightned, I thank Heaven and you. Now, pray, read Sir my Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: In Dei nomine. Amen.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: O let us heare the Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I Iane Tryman of Knockers hole, in the County of Cornwall, Widdow, Sick in Body, but whole in Mind, and of perfect memory, do make my last Will and Testament, in Manner and Forme following.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: As for the Manner and Forme tis no matter. To the Legacies, briefly.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hum hum. Imprimis, A Dole of Bread to be given to the Poore of this Parish— five pound.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Stay. This I intreat of you Mr. Wolsey, that whether I live or dye, this Dole may be given to morrow. It was the Charge of my Mother to see it done; Saying, it was better to take the Prayers of the Poore with me, then leave them to be sent after.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: It shall be done: and you, I hope, shall see it.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
To Mr. Sarpego, the Writer hereof, A Mourning
Gown, and forty pound, to Preach at the Funerall.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How! forty pound?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Di boni! No. Tis forty shillings. Item to my Nephew, Sir Marmaduke Trevaugh an of St. Minever, one thousand pound in Gold. Item to my Nephew Mr. Francis Trepton, one thousand pound in Gold. Item to my Kinsman, Sir Stephen Leggleden, I do forgive two thousand pound, for which his Lands are Mortgaged to me. Item to his Daughter, my God-daughter Iane Leggleden, five hundred pound in money; my best Bason and Ewer; two silver Flaggon Pots, and three silver and gilt standing Cups. Item to the poore of the Parish of Knockers-hole, ten pound, and forty pound towards the reparation of their Church. Item to Mr. Linsey wolsey the Ring, which was my Wedding Ring, and fifty other Rings, with severall stones in my Trunck, in his house, valued at two hundred and fifty pounds. Item to all his servants, and to the Women that attended me in my sicknesse, five pound a piece.

sp.speaker: Jone.
sp.p: Now the Lord receive her to his mercy.

sp.speaker: Isa
sp.p: My Legacy will save her life; for never any body dyed yet, that bequeathed me any thing.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Item, to my Page Jeffery Crack forty pound. And all my other Servants ten pound a peice. Item to my Neece Barbara Tredrite five hundred pound; my second Bason and Ewer, a dozen of silver Dishes, and four dozen of silver Spoones. Lastly, all the rest of my Lands, Jewels, Plate, Money, Debts, Moveables and Unmoveables, to my dear and loving Brother, Sir Gregory Flamsted, whom I make my full Executor. In cujus rei testimonium, &c. This is the briefe of it.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p:
Tis well. Onely add to it— Uh— A Gold Chaine also in my Trunk to this vertuous Gentlewoman.
And another Chaine, that is there of Pearle, to her Daughter. To this learned Doctor twenty pound. And to the Gentlemen which have visited me, for them and their freinds an hundred pound to be spent in a Banckquet.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hoc nihil refert. I must write all over againe then.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Do so then. And make your forty shillings five pound.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Gratias vel ingentes ago. It shall be done—

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Now Mr. Wolsie, and your vertuous Neighbour here, I intreat, that when I have signed this Will, that you keep it til my Brother comes to Town. This Doctor shall direct you in all. And that he may be the better able so to do, I desire you all that I may a while be private with him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Are they all gone?
Now Mr. Doctor, what think you of the sick Widow?
Has she done her part hitherto?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Beyond my expectation! Better then I for a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: You are right. And I am even the same for a Widow as you for a Doctor. Do not I know you? Yes good Mr. Crasy. I dare trust you, because you must trust me. Therefore know, that I the rich Widow am no better, then a Lady that must live by what I beare about me. The vulgar translation you know, but let them speak their pleasure, I have no Lands, and since I am borne, must be kept, I may make the best of my owne, and if one member maintaine the whole body, what's that to any one?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I collected as much by your young Whiskin that brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: It was by my direction that he did so. And, by my Instructions, he has had an Eye upon you in all your disguises ever since your pretended Journey out of Towne. Nay startle not, nor muse at my acquaintance with you: I have had you in my Purlews, before you were a Freeman: And will hereafter give you certaine tokens of it. In the mean time, if you comply with me, you can be no loofer by it. I am grown weary of my old course; and would faine, by wiser, do my selfe good, before Age or Diseases make it too late.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will work close and friendly with thee. Therefore say, this rich Cockscombe is thine owne. O here comes your Pigg-wiggen.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: He is of Counsell, and one of us. He is indeed my Brother, and has been one of the true blew Boyes of the Hospitall; one of the sweet singers to the City Funeralls with a two penny loafe under his arme.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Well: He never sung to the wheele in Saint Brides Nunnery yonder.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Nay Jeff, be not angry; thou hast sung to the Organs I know, till fearing their downfall, thou betookst thy selfe into my more certaine service. All freinds, good Jeff.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we must all agree, and be linckt in Covenant together.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: By Indenture Tripartite, and't please you, like Subtle, Doll, and Face.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Witty Jeff. I cannot see which can be spar'd from the rest, least the whole trade break.

lg.l: Then let us be freinds, and most freindly agree.
The Pimp and the Punck and the Doctor are three,
That cannot but thrive, when united they be.
The Pimp brings in custome, the Punck shee gets treasure,
Of which the Physitian is sure of his measure,
For work that she makes him in sale of her pleasure.
For which, when she failes by diseases or paine,
The Doctor new Vamps and upsets her againe.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Thou art a brave Lad, and in the high way of preferment.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Not the high Holborne way, I hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: And for you Damsell, as I sayd before, say to your selfe, the Match is yours.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I mean to say, and know it shortly. Some three dayes hence all may be compleated. Now draw the Curtaines; and follow your affaires, while I put on my sick Face againe. Uh, uh, uh.

div.stage: They put in the Bed, and withdraw all. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene II.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: NOw could I Accost that Catlinarian Traytor, that defeated me of my ten pound, I have a precogitated Oration should make him suspend himselfe. But Abiit, evasit, erupit. Or if the rich Widow would have dyed, there had been a supply. But she is nearer a Nuptiall, then a Funerall: And hopelesse Sarpego, that should wed, has not to furnish him to his intent, Vae mihi misero nec Aurum, nec Argent— tum! Here comes my Beatitude.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O, are you here Sir? I was to seek you. My old Mistresse would speak with you instantly.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: My Legitimate Spouse, when is our day of conjunction?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Our day of conjunction? Mary faugh Goodman Fiste. Our day of conjunction?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Did you not once vow you did love me?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Did not you once swear you had money?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hic jacet, I am now but a dead man.

div.stage: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Crasie— like a Court-Messenger.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: O where's Mr. Sarpego? Fortunate Mr. Sarpego? Venerable Mr. Sarpego? O Sir, you are made. Never thinke under right worshipfull. Imagine nothing beneath Damasque Gownes, Velvet Jackets, Satten Sleeves, Silk Nightcaps, two Pages and a Footcloth.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: The Son of Phoebus rectifie your Brain-pan.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Indeed, and't shall please your Worship, it is—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: It is! What is it? You will be speaking, will you? And your Wife in presence, will you? you shew your bringing up. Master Sarpego, blesse the time that ever you knew the Progeny of the Sneakups: my worshipfull Son and Heire apparent hath preferred you to be the young Prince his Tutor. Here's Mr. Holywater, a Gentleman; of place, a Courtier; of Office, is sent for you.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Right fortunately-learned Sir. So passionately doth his Grace approve the Language, Literature, and Haviour of your sometimes Pupill, Master Tobias Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Umh.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: That I was, with all expedition, commanded to intreat your instant Attendance.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Umh Umh—

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: 'Tis even so Sir; You are like to possess a Princes eare; you may be in place, where you may scorn your foes; countenance your friends; cherish vertue, controule vice, and despise fortune: Yes sure shall you Sir. And (which I had almost forgot) your old Pupill intreats you to send him by me the ten pound he lent you: An od ten pound, that he may be furnish'd with the more seemly Complements to conduct you to his Grace.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Quid nunc?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Whist Mr. Sarpego. Let not your poverty be read in your face. Here's ten pieces. Bear it as your own payment: You talk of ten pound for my Son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O, an od driblet. Here, Friend, I use not to carry Silver: Convey it in Gold.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I hope, dear Love, you will not forget your affection to me now.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Poor Maid, I will prefer thee to scratch my head; make my Bed; wash my Shirt, pick my toes, and evacuate my Chamberpot. I will instantly procure mee attire, fitting my fortune, and attend the Grace of Court—

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Now am I but a dead woman.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I am much griev'd for't. It was your sonnes much labouring, that Mr. Crasie was sent for, to sell his Grace some Jewells: But since his fortunes are so sunk that he hides his head, I can but lament his losse.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Shall I tell you Sir, (pray you husband stand aside;) My Son-in-Law Crasie is not now worth— his very wife. We hop'd he would have prov'd a crafty Merchant, and he prov'd an honest man, a Begger (if I chance to speak above your capacity, I pray tell me of
it) And as I said, when I perceiv'd he began to melt, and that every stranger abused him; I, having some wit, fell too, and most cozen'd him my self. I look'd for my daughters good: And so betwixt us, found the trick to get, or steale from him two Jewells of good deep value, being indeed the main of his rest of Fortune. Now Sir, I come to you.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I, now you come to the point.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Right Sir: For there is no woman, though she use never so many by-words, but yet in the end she will come to the point. Now Sir, I having these Jewells, will send them by my husband. A poor easie weak man, as you see; but very obedient in truth—

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: By your husband.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Yes, do you mark? By my husband. But now note my wit: His Grace knows not Crasie: My husband, habited like a Citizen, shall take the name of Crasie upon him; offer his Jewells to the Prince; you shall present them; praise them and raise them: His Grace payes; my husband returns; and we will share. Do you approve?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Nay admire.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Away then. No Complement among good wits; but away. Come your ways hither, good man; Put off your hat; Make a leg; Look simply. Why so! Pish, ne're tell me: He will make a rare Citizen. I have Jewells for you to carry to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, I'le carry them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
La! you are so quick! I have charg'd you not to shoot your bolt, before you understand your mark. And you shall carry them like a Citizen; call your self Crasie; sell them at my price; and now cast no further. You see the limits of your understanding. Now Sir, how will you bear your self to his Grace?
How behave your selfe at Court?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I hope I am not too wise to learne.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why, that was well spoken. Modest mistrust is the first step to knowledge. Remember that sentence. Now mark. I will instruct you: When you come at the Court gate, you may neither knocke nor pisse. Do you mark? You go through the Hall cover'd; through the great Chamber cover'd; through the Presence bare; through the Lobby cover'd; through the Privy Chamber bare; through the Privy Lobby cover'd; to the Prince bare.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I'le doe't I warrant you. Let me see. At the Court gate neither knock nor make water. May not a man break wind?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Umh, yes: but (like the Exchequer payment) somewhat abated.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Through the great Chamber bare.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Cover'd.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Cover'd? Well: Through the Presence cover'd.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Bare.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Bare? I will put all downe in my Table-book, and con it by the way.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well thought on. Something he has in him like my husband! But now you come before the brow of Royalty. Now for your carriage there Sir: Suppose me the Prince. Come in, and present. Here sits the Prince. There enters the Jeweller. Make your honors. Let me see you do it handsomly.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes, now I come in; make my three legs— And then—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Kneele.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes; and say—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Nay, that I know not.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: An't please your Grace, I have certain Jewells to present to your liking.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: An't please your Grace, I have certain Jewels to present to your liking.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Is this Crasie, that had wont to serve me with Jewells? It is that honest man, so please your Highnesse. That's for M. Holywater, the by-flatterer to speak. You are a Cuckoldly Knave, Sirrah, and have often abused me with false and deceitfull stones.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: My stones are right, so please your Excellence.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why that was well, Very well. I perceive there is a certain infection taken with lying with a woman that hath a good wit. I finde it by my husband. Come, I'le disguise you, and away to Court instantly.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Truly wife, I fear J shall be discover'd among the Gallants presently.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: No, no, A fool is never discover'd among mad-men.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p:
WEll Dol, (that thou saist is thy name) though J had forgotten thee, J protest. About London-wall was it (saist thou?) Well, J cannot but highly commend thy wisdom in this, that so
well hast mended thy election; from being a fountain of aches, bald brows, and broad plasters, thus to remember thy Creation.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I did consider, and I thinke rightly, what I was; and that men that lov'd my use, lov'd it but to loath me: Therefore I chang'd my self into this shape of a demure, innocent Countrey Widdow, that had scarce beauty enough to be tempted, but not wit enough to be naught; and quite forsook the path I trod in, and betook me to this private course of cozenage.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: But all my wonder is at the means, how thou gott'st into this house and reputation. And to be held a woman of such an estate.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: That shall bee made plaine to you hereafter.
Now Brother Geffrey, where left you M Wolsie?

sp.speaker: Crack.
sp.p: Among the Mercers, so troubled, as if all the Sattin in Cheapside were not enough to make you a wedding Gowne. He is over-joy'd that his happy day is at hand; and I over-heard him invite one speciall friend to his Nuptialls. He cannot contain himself. On a sudden he fell a singing, O shee's a dainty Widdow. O are you come Sir, in your new shape? Dos not that beard fit you handsomly? Thank my acquaintance with the Players.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I thinke thou art acquainted any way, to set out knavery.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: If you can perform your part as well, 'tis well. Heark, I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Where are you sweet Widdow? Look you, Look you: How do you like these patterns?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Gentleman has a Letter to you: He tells me it imports the making, or the undoing of his dearest friend.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: From whom, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your sometimes neighbor Sir, M: Crasy.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: It shall take effect, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: He scratches his head, though.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: He had as liefe part with his blood as his money.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: M. Crasy writes to me for thirty pound; the value of a Ring I had of him. I grant I am to pay threescore at my day of Marriage. But we are all mortall. And who knowes whether I shall live till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: If not, Sir, your Bond is due to night: For it is equally payable at your hour of death.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O, but such payments never trouble a man. What the eye sees not—

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Are you in Bonds, M. Woolsie, for your day of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Only for this sixty pound. 'Tis for that Ring you weare, and I gave you upon our Contract. 'Tis worth thirty pound ready mony.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Then when you are married, you may say you paid the rest for your wife. Pray Sir make even such reckonings before you wed. It will shew nobly in you towards your poor Creditor, and be a speciall argument of your love to me, your wife. Pray discharge it, I shall not think you love me else.

Heark you Sir, if you will take thirty pound in full
payment, and give me in my Bond, here is your mony. 'Tis your best course. Alas, I am an unlikely fellow for wedlock. What woman, thinke you, would bestow her self upon me, a stale Batchellor, unhandsome and poor— not worth above six or seven thousand pound? Do; take thirty pound.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: If you please to be friend Mr. Crasy but wich thirty pound, Ile set it receiv'd upon the Bond. Here it is. And he shall demand no more till it be due.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray Sir pay it all, and take in your Bond. You shall be married within these two dayes; to morrow, if you please: What use will your money yeeld you for a night? Pray pay it. In truth I'le pay it else. 'Tis but threescore pound.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Saist thou so, Sweetheart. Come Sir. Come in and tell your money—

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: And thank you too, good M. Linsie Wolsie, that knew so well, a bargaine was a bargaine, and would not part with your money to be laugh'd at among your neighbours. I would heartily now, if I could intend it. But I must purse your money, and then about my Court affairs. This wench I am infinitely beholden to. She remembers some old curtesie that I have forgotten. Perhaps I pidled with her when I was Prentice.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: THis is the Presence. I am much amaz'd, or stupified, that Mr. Tobias Sneakup, my quondam Pupill, attends not my Conduct! Ha! So instant was his Grace, his importunity to enjoy me, that although I purchased the loan of Cloaths, yet I had not vacation, nor indeed variety to shift my shirt. And now I come to Court, I feel certain little Cattell of infamous generation about me, that do most inseparably haunt me. Now if (when the Prince surveyes me) any of them being strangers here, should peep to behold strange sights, and his Grace perceive them, what should I answer?—

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: O, my glorified Pedant in his most naturall strut!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I will say it was by influence of the heavens; or, to appear the more perfect Courtier at the first dash, I will say, that though my outside were glorious, yet of purpose I left my inside lowsie.
Sed, O Dii! Quem video? nonne Mr. Sneakup?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: See my worshipfull Father-in-Law! Now the Woodcocks shoot into the glade.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray ye peace, you must not know me.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O monstrum horrendum! May not you and I know one another?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray go home, and ask my wife.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Mr. Crasie. Is not one Mr. Crasie here?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes Sir. Here is Mr. Crasie for a need Sir.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Well done: Be bold Sir. Let not your dissimulation be read in your eyes. You know me; give me the Jewells.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Let me alone to present them to his Grace, and praise them, before you are call'd.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Will you do so Sir?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Yes; For you know I must not seem to indeare them before your face: For that would smell rank of correspondency.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: You say right Sir.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: But betwixt us both wee'l make a shift to cheat him. Stay you here. I will returne instantly. O Mr. Sarpego! Your Pupill will come and conduct you presently.

lg.l: Thus sometimes, by deceit, deceit is known:
'Tis honest craft, by wit to get ones own.—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: My Quondam Pedagogue!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: My Nuper Alumnus! Come, present me to the Grace of Greatness. I am ready; behold I am approach'd according to thy intreats, to approve thy praise, and mine own perfection. Set on: His Grace shall see that we can speake true Latin, and construe Ludovicus vives: Go, set on.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Sir. Upon my troth, I tooke you for Mr. Sarpego, my learned Tutor. He is very like him; Is he not Gentlemen? But now I come to my selfe againe, I remember this was never his walke, nor these his cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Sent you not a Nuntius, or a Messenger for me, intimating, that it was his Grace his instant desire, to entertain me as his Instructor?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Alas, he has over-studied himself! You were best let blood in time Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Sent I not you, by the same messenger, your ten pound?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My ten pound? Ha, ha ha: I would laugh i faith, if you could bob me off with such payment.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sure Sir, you use some Dormitaries. Best shave your head, and 'noint it with Oyl of Roses.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Father! Father!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray peace son. The plot will be discover'd else.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The plot? what plot?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: The Jewells are sent in, What, I am Mr. Crasie now, you know. I shall be sent for in to his Grace instantly.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Midsummer Moon! Midsummer Moon!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: In very truth son, hit as 'twill, I say we are beholding to Mr. Holywater.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Heaven not blesse me, if I understand not the Baboons mumpings better then your speech. You are more dark then Delphos. What Holywater?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Why the Gentleman, you know, you sent to bring M. Crasie to serve his Grace with Jewells.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Father, Heaven pardon me: For sure I have a great desire to call you Cockscomb. I sent no man; nor is there any so stiled as Holywater about the Court.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Do you not want sleep sir?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or have you not seen a spirit sir?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Or have you not over-mus'd, or over-thought your selfe, as wee doubt Mr. Sarpego, here, has done?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Or has not my mother over-beaten you, father? You may tell me.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Son, I am not so very a foole, but I perceive I am made a stark Asse. Oh sonne, thy father is cozen'd; and thy mother will beat me indeed, unlesse your charity conceal me in the Court here, till her fury be over.

sp.speaker: Ticket.
sp.p: Hee shall stay at my Wives Chamber.

sp.speaker: Rufflit.
sp.p: And there instruct us in the passages of this cozenage.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Do not weep father. My Lady Ticket will appease all.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Adieu Mr. Sarpego. Lure your braines backe againe.

sp.speaker: Sar.
